title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid justification, based on bonding type, equivalent to the following.

· Disagree. The reaction of a metal with a highly electronegative nonmetal (nitrogen) will produce an ionic bond. Polar covalent bonds would be formed if both elements were nonmetals and had significantly different electronegativities.

The response provides both the correct answer and a valid justification, based on bonding type, equivalent to the following.

· Disagree. The reaction of a metal with a highly electronegative nonmetal (nitrogen) will produce an ionic bond. Polar covalent bonds would be formed if both elements were nonmetals and had significantly different electronegativities.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct diagram choice and a valid justification, based on number of peaks and relative position of reactant and product energies, equivalent to the following.

· Diagram 2. The potential energy of the products is lower than that of the reactants, which is consistent with an exothermic reaction. The diagram also has three peaks, corresponding to a three-step mechanism.

The response includes both the correct diagram choice and a valid justification, based on number of peaks and relative position of reactant and product energies, equivalent to the following.

· Diagram 2. The potential energy of the products is lower than that of the reactants, which is consistent with an exothermic reaction. The diagram also has three peaks, corresponding to a three-step mechanism.

descriptions:
The response does not provide both the correct answer and a valid justification, based on average speed presented in the plot, equivalent to the following.

· R has a molar mass less than that of N 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGobWaaSbaaS qaaiaaikdaaeqaaaaa@3AB6@ . Since the curve for R is shifted further to the right, and the average speed is higher, a particle of R must be less massive than a particle of N 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbtv2zVvgiqjxAUrharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeGaeaaakeaacaqGobWaaSbaaS qaaiaaikdaaeqaaaaa@3AB6@ . According to KMT, less massive particles with the same average kinetic energy (temperature) move with higher average speed.
